title: 107_s664
content: The Act titled "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" establishes jurisdictional standards for state and local business activity, sales, and use tax obligations on interstate commerce. It amends Title I of the Act approved on September 14, 1959, to address the imposition of these tax obligations. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. This includes solicitation of orders for sales fulfilled outside the state. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. This includes solicitation of orders for sales fulfilled outside the state, presence or use of intangible personal property, and the use of the Internet for business activities. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. This includes using the Internet to create or maintain a website accessible in the state, utilizing Internet service providers for orders processing, and affiliating with a person in the state under specific conditions. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. This includes using an unaffiliated representative or independent contractor in the state for warranty or repair services. The act also exempts domestic corporations and individuals domiciled in or residents of the state from certain tax obligations. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. This includes sales or solicitation of orders by independent contractors on behalf of a person, without attributing substantial physical presence to another person. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" prohibits states from imposing business activity or sales/use tax on income from interstate commerce without substantial physical presence in the state. It defines an independent contractor as someone engaged in selling or soliciting orders for tangible or intangible goods. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" defines an independent contractor as someone who sells or solicits orders for goods or services for multiple principals in the regular course of business activities. The term 'Internet' refers to the interconnected network of computer and telecommunications facilities, while 'Internet access' enables users to access online content and services. The "New Economy Tax Fairness Act or NET FAIR Act" defines terms like representative, sales tax, solicitation of orders or contracts, and State in relation to services offered to users. The term 'State' includes States, the District of Columbia, territories, or possessions of the United States. 'Use tax' is a tax on tangible or intangible property or services based on purchase price. 'World Wide Web' refers to a server-based file archive accessible over the Internet. This section clarifies that it does not limit constitutional restrictions on State taxing authority. Section 102 prohibits States from assessing business activity taxes on income derived from activities within the State that affect interstate commerce if such tax imposition is prohibited by section 101. It does not invalidate the collection of taxes imposed before the enactment date or prohibit the collection of taxes assessed before that date. SEC. 103 states that if a person obligated to pay business activity tax or collect sales/use tax in a State no longer has substantial physical presence there, the obligation applies only during the period of physical presence. SEC. 104 ensures that if any provision of the title is deemed invalid, the rest of the title remains unaffected.
